text: Continental tectonic plates drift at the same speed fingernails grow - up to 20 millimeters per year.

Scientists have catalogued 402 bright streaks (lineae) on Mercury's surface that tend to cluster on sun-facing slopes of craters - they may still be forming today through the flow of heat and volatile materials like sulfur from below.
Planet Earth news, feature and articles Earth is one big spinning mystery in a constant state of change.
By Ashley Hamer Published 27 October 25 4 Comments Plants Fruits and vegetables quiz: Do you know where pumpkins, blueberries and broccoli come from?
By Dr Jo Cutler Published 28 November 25 Climate change World's first global carbon tax was about to be introduced.

With more than 4.5 billion years of history locked inside a ball of molten rock and iron, our planet is made up of a vast array of geological wonders, carved by the oceans, shaped by the shifting plates beneath our feet and sculpted by weather across the surface.

Our team of expert science writers and editors are here to reveal our planet’s secrets — from the deepest depths of the ocean , through the coldest places on Earth to the very edge of space — keeping you up to date with the latest discoveries with planet Earth news, articles and features.

Antarctica 6 million-year-old ice discovered in Antarctica shatters records — and there's ancient air trapped inside Exoplanets Strange discovery offers 'missing link' in planet formation Space Is there anything 'below' Earth in space?

By Laura Geggel Published 23 October 25 Plants Plants self-organize in a 'hidden order,' echoing pattern found across nature By Olivia Ferrari Published 22 October 25 5 Comments Plants Pollution Are biodegradable plastics really worth the hype?
By Naveena Sadasivam Published 22 November 25 Climate change Global warming is forcing Earth's systems toward 'doom loop' tipping points.
The Kola Superdeep Borehole in Russia reaches 12,262 meters deep - the deepest artificial point on Earth, where temperatures reach 180°C.
Mauna Kea in Hawaii rises 10,203 meters from its oceanic base - taller than Mount Everest when measured from base to peak.
The Nile River stretches 6,650 km through northeastern Africa, making it the longest river in the world.
The Amazon River carries more water than any other river - about 20% of all freshwater flowing into the world's oceans.
The Yangtze River stretches 6,300 km across China, making it the longest river in Asia and third longest in the world.
The Yellow River (Huang He) is 5,464 km long and carries so much sediment that it gives the water its distinctive yellow color.
The Mississippi River flows 3,766 km through the heart of North America, draining about 40% of the continental United States.
The Volga River at 3,530 km is Europe's longest river and drains into the Caspian Sea.
The Mekong River stretches 4,350 km through six countries in Southeast Asia, feeding 60 million people.
The Congo River is 4,700 km long and is the deepest river in the world, reaching depths of 220 meters.
The Brahmaputra River flows 2,900 km and drops 4,500 meters from its source in Tibet to the Bay of Bengal.
The Indus River is 3,180 km long and gave India its name - 'Indus' comes from Sanskrit 'Sindhu' meaning river.
Mount Olympus in Greece rises 2,918 meters and was believed by ancient Greeks to be the home of the gods.
The Lena River in Siberia is 4,294 km long and remains frozen for 7-8 months of the year.
The Yenisei River at 3,487 km is the largest river system flowing into the Arctic Ocean.
The Ob River in Russia is 3,650 km long and its basin contains some of the world's largest wetlands.
The Niger River flows 4,180 km through West Africa and uniquely curves away from the sea before turning back toward it.

A 'mystery eruption' cooled the Northern Hemisphere in 1453.
A hypothesized land bridge (GAARlandia) may have allowed some fish species to migrate from South America to Cuba.
Geologist Gilbert Wilson was the fifth Wilson at school, so he was known as 'Quintus'.
English amateur geologist Charlotte Eyton wrote a number of papers and pamphlets on the geology of the Wrekin, Shropshire, between 1862 and 1870.
Aucklanders have a reputation for making false earthquake reports on New Zealand's earthquake monitoring website GeoNet.
Deep Cut Gardens in New Jersey contains a stone replica of Mount Vesuvius that once erupted smoke at the behest of mobster Vito Genovese.
Some Lake Superior agates have circular, concentric rings on their surfaces, called 'eyes'.
The Siderian is currently the earliest internationally recognized geological period.
Giorgina Reid patented a technique for holding up banks (erosion prevention on coastal banks).
The depth value is measured from the highest to the lowest accessible cave point.

While many eruptions only pose dangers to the immediately surrounding area, Earth's largest eruptions can have a major regional or even global impact, with some affecting the climate and contributing to mass extinctions.
An eruptive phase can consist of a single eruption, or a sequence of several eruptions spread over several days, weeks or months.

Despite their ostensibly benign appearance, effusive eruptions can be as dangerous as explosive ones: one of the largest effusive eruptions in history occurred in Iceland during the 1783–1784 eruption of Laki, which produced about 15 km3 (4 cu mi) of lava and killed one fifth of Iceland's population.
The ensuing disruptions to the climate may also have killed millions elsewhere.
These can comprise hundreds of large eruptions, producing millions of cubic kilometers of lava in total.
No large eruptions of flood basalts have occurred in human history, the most recent having occurred over 10 million years ago.
They are often associated with breakup of supercontinents such as Pangea in the geologic record, and may have contributed to a number of mass extinctions.
The latter is the most recent large igneous province, and also one of the smallest.
Russia has more surface area than Pluto.
The world's deepest cave is Veryovkina Cave at 2,212 meters.
The world's highest waterfall is Angel Falls at 979 meters.
The world's largest iceberg was larger than the island of Jamaica.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all the land on Earth combined.
Mount Everest grows about 4 mm per year.
The Atlantic Ocean grows 2.5 cm wider every year.
The world's longest river is the Nile at 6,650 km.
The world's deepest lake is Lake Baikal at 5,387 feet.
The world's largest cave is in Vietnam.
The world's smallest country is Vatican City at 0.17 square miles.
The world's longest cave system is Mammoth Cave at 400 miles.
The world's largest salt flat is Salar de Uyuni.
The world's longest river is the Nile at 4,132 miles.
The world's largest island is Greenland.
The world's highest waterfall is Angel Falls at 3,212 feet.
The world's largest hot desert is the Sahara.
The world's largest bay is the Bay of Bengal.
The world's largest peninsula is Arabia.
The world's longest glacier is in Antarctica at 250 miles.
The world's highest capital city is La Paz, Bolivia.
The world's largest delta is the Ganges Delta.
The world's largest estuary is the St. Lawrence.
The world's largest lagoon is in New Caledonia.
The world's largest atoll is Kiritimati.
The world's largest fjord is Scoresby Sund.
The world's largest archipelago is Indonesia.
The world's highest mountain from base to peak is Mauna Kea.
The world's longest mountain range is the Andes at 4,500 miles.
The world's largest plateau is the Tibetan Plateau.
The world's highest active volcano is Ojos del Salado.
The world's largest volcanic caldera is Toba.
The world's deepest freshwater lake is Lake Baikal.
The world's largest underground lake is in Namibia.
The world's highest navigable lake is Lake Titicaca.
The world's longest underwater cave is in Mexico.
The world's largest floating ice shelf is Ross Ice Shelf.
The world's deepest submarine cave is in Czechia.
The world's longest road is the Pan-American Highway at 19,000 miles.
The world's largest desert is Antarctica.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space without aid.
The deepest hole ever drilled is the Kola Superdeep Borehole in Russia at 12.3 km — it took 20 years to drill and temperatures at the bottom reached 180°C.
There's enough gold dissolved in the world's oceans to give every person 9 pounds of gold, but it's too diluted to extract economically.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun — about 5,400°C.
Yellowstone's supervolcano has enough magma to fill the Grand Canyon 11 times over and erupts catastrophically every 600,000 years — it's overdue.
Antarctica was once a tropical rainforest, and fossils of palm trees and dinosaurs have been found there.
The Earth's magnetic poles flip roughly every 200,000-300,000 years — the last flip was 780,000 years ago, so we're overdue.
The Himalayas grow about 1 cm per year due to the Indian subcontinent still crashing into Asia.
Lake Baikal in Russia contains 22% of the world's fresh surface water — more than all the Great Lakes combined.
The Dead Sea is so salty that you can float in it effortlessly, but it's also shrinking by about 3 feet per year.
Mount Everest grows about 4mm per year and is still rising due to tectonic forces.
The Pacific Ocean is shrinking by about an inch per year while the Atlantic Ocean is getting wider.
There's a hidden continent called Zealandia that's 94% submerged beneath the Pacific Ocean.
Approximately 80% of volcanic eruptions happen underwater, and we've explored less than 5% of the ocean floor.
The Sahara Desert was a lush, green savanna with lakes and rivers just 6,000 years ago.
There's a cave in Mexico called the Cave of Crystals containing gypsum crystals up to 12 meters long — the largest natural crystals ever found.
Earthquakes can make gold appear — sudden pressure drops during quakes cause water in rock faults to vaporize, depositing gold.
The Amazon River once flowed into the Pacific Ocean before the Andes Mountains rose up and reversed its direction.
The Great Blue Hole in Belize is a perfectly circular underwater sinkhole 318 meters across and 124 meters deep.
Plate tectonics didn't start until about a billion years after Earth formed — the early Earth had a single solid shell.
The oldest rocks on Earth are about 4.4 billion years old, found in Western Australia.
The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa was heard 3,000 miles away and the sound circled the Earth four times.
There's a 'Door to Hell' in Turkmenistan — a burning natural gas crater that's been on fire since 1971.
The driest place on Earth isn't the Sahara — it's the Dry Valleys of Antarctica, which haven't seen rain for 2 million years.
Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador is technically 'taller' than Everest if measured from Earth's center, due to the planet's equatorial bulge.
The Earth's crust is proportionally thinner than an eggshell compared to the planet's size.
The Moho discontinuity marks where Earth's crust ends and mantle begins — no human has ever reached it.
The 2011 Japan earthquake was so powerful it shifted Earth's axis by 4 inches and shortened the day by 1.8 microseconds.
Angel Falls in Venezuela is so tall (979 meters) that water turns to mist before reaching the bottom.
Blood Falls in Antarctica seeps iron-rich water that looks exactly like blood pouring from a glacier.
The Danakil Depression in Ethiopia is the hottest inhabited place on Earth with average temperatures of 34.4°C.
Lava flows can reach temperatures of 1,200°C — hot enough to melt glass and some metals.
The Earth's inner core spins faster than the rest of the planet, completing an extra rotation every 400 years.
Petrified lightning, called fulgurite, forms when lightning strikes sand and fuses it into glass tubes.
There's a pink lake in Australia called Lake Hillier whose color has never been fully explained.
The Richat Structure in Mauritania is a 50-km-wide circular formation visible from space, once thought to be an impact crater but now believed to be eroded rock.
Oil and coal are made from ancient organisms — a gallon of gasoline required about 98 tons of prehistoric plant material.
The world's largest cave passage is in Vietnam's Hang Son Doong, big enough to fit a 40-story building.
Volcanic lightning occurs when ash particles collide and create static electricity during eruptions.
The Hawaiian Islands are moving northwest at about 7-9 cm per year due to plate tectonics.
Diamonds can form in just minutes under the extreme pressures of asteroid impacts.
Mount Erebus in Antarctica has a permanent lava lake and is the southernmost active volcano on Earth.
Underground fires can burn for decades or centuries — the Centralia mine fire in Pennsylvania has burned since 1962.
The oldest water on Earth was found 2 miles underground in Canada and is about 2 billion years old.
Pumice is the only rock that floats on water because it's full of gas bubbles from volcanic eruptions.
The Mid-Atlantic Ridge is the longest mountain range on Earth at 65,000 km, but it's almost entirely underwater.
The average iceberg weighs 20 million tons.
The loudest sound ever recorded was the 1883 Krakatoa eruption.
The deepest hole ever drilled is only 12 km deep — 0.2% of Earth's radius.
Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun.
There are over 1 million earthquakes per year, most too small to feel.
The Sahara was green with rivers and lakes just 6,000 years ago.
The Dead Sea is shrinking by about 3 feet per year.
Mount Everest grows about 4mm per year due to tectonic forces.
Antarctica contains 70% of Earth's fresh water.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all landmasses combined.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun.
The Great Barrier Reef can be seen from space.
The Sahara Desert was once a lush tropical forest.
The Mariana Trench is deeper than Mount Everest is tall.
The Sahara Desert was once a tropical rainforest.
The world's largest volcano is underwater.
The world's smallest country is Vatican City.
The world's longest river is the Nile.
The world's deepest lake is Lake Baikal.
The world's tallest waterfall is Angel Falls.
Impact craters on Earth erode over time.
Meteor Crater in Arizona is 1 km wide.
Vredefort Crater is the largest known impact crater.
Geothermal energy is renewable and sustainable.
Iceland generates 25% of electricity from geothermal.
Hot springs can support unique ecosystems.
Yellowstone has over 10,000 geothermal features.
Mud pots are acidic hot springs.
Fumaroles release volcanic gases.
Solfataras emit sulfurous gases.
The Sudbury Basin was formed by an asteroid impact 1.8 billion years ago.
The Manicouagan Reservoir is a visible impact crater from space.
Shatter cones are evidence of ancient impacts.
Tektites are glassy rocks formed by meteor impacts.
Impactites form when rock is melted by impacts.
Iridium is rare on Earth but common in asteroids.
The Deccan Traps may have contributed to dinosaur extinction.
The Siberian Traps caused the largest mass extinction.
Flood basalts cover millions of square kilometers.
The Columbia River Basalt Group covers Washington state.
Hotspots create volcanic island chains.
The Hawaiian Islands formed over a hotspot.
Yellowstone sits on a supervolcano hotspot.
The Iceland hotspot created the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
The Réunion hotspot may have caused the Deccan Traps.
Mantle plumes rise from near the core.
The D" layer is at the base of the mantle.
The inner core is solid iron and nickel.
The outer core is liquid iron and nickel.
The Moho discontinuity separates crust from mantle.
P-waves travel faster than S-waves.
S-waves cannot travel through liquids.
The shadow zone proves Earth has a liquid outer core.
Love waves cause the most earthquake damage.
Rayleigh waves move in elliptical patterns.
The Richter scale is logarithmic.
The moment magnitude scale replaced the Richter scale.
The largest recorded earthquake was magnitude 9.5 in Chile.
Japan has the most earthquake monitoring stations.
The San Andreas Fault is 800 miles long.
The Cascadia Subduction Zone threatens the Pacific Northwest.
Subduction zones produce the largest earthquakes.
The Ring of Fire has 75% of Earth's volcanoes.
There are about 1,350 potentially active volcanoes.
Mauna Loa is the largest volcano on Earth.
Mount Tambora's eruption caused the Year Without a Summer.
Krakatoa's explosion was heard 3,000 miles away.
Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980.
Pompeii was buried by Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD.
Volcanic lightning occurs during eruptions.
Lahars are volcanic mudflows.
Pyroclastic flows can travel at 450 mph.
Lava tubes can be miles long.
Pahoehoe lava has a smooth, ropy surface.
Aa lava has a rough, jagged surface.
Obsidian is volcanic glass.
Pumice is the only rock that floats.
Geysers erupt when groundwater is heated by magma.
Old Faithful erupts about every 90 minutes.
The Great Wall of China isn't visible from space.
The Pacific Ocean covers more area than all landmasses combined.
Diamonds aren't rare — the diamond industry controls supply to keep prices high. There are enough diamonds mined each year to give everyone on Earth a ring.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all land combined.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space with the naked eye, despite popular belief.
The longest place name in the world is Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu in New Zealand.
The only letter that doesn't appear in any U.S. state name is Q.
Maine is the closest U.S. state to Africa.
The Atlantic Ocean grows about 1 inch wider every year due to tectonic plate movement.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 30 miles per year.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun, about 5,500°C.
Mount Everest grows about 4 millimeters taller each year due to tectonic activity.
The longest river in the world is the Nile at approximately 6,650 km (4,130 miles).
The largest volcanic eruption in recorded history was Mount Tambora in 1815.
The world's largest desert is Antarctica, which is a polar desert.
The longest place name in the world has 85 letters and is a hill in New Zealand.
The Vatican City is the smallest country in the world at just 0.17 square miles.
Lake Baikal in Russia contains about 20% of the world's unfrozen fresh water.
The driest place on Earth is the Atacama Desert in Chile, where some areas haven't seen rain in 400 years.
The largest diamond ever found was the Cullinan, weighing 3,106 carats.
The largest recorded earthquake was a magnitude 9.5 in Chile in 1960.
The largest cave in the world is Son Doong in Vietnam, large enough to hold a 40-story building.
The Amazon River releases 20% of all fresh water that flows into the world's oceans.
The Earth's magnetic field flips approximately every 200,000 to 300,000 years.
The deepest man-made hole is the Kola Superdeep Borehole at 40,230 feet.
The Earth's magnetic field protects us from about 99% of harmful solar radiation.
